Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Towards a Definitive Test of DAMA's Annual Modulation Signal
Award.AbstractNarration:
Astrophysical observations and cosmological data have led to the unambiguous conclusion that nearly a quarter of the Universe consists of dark matter. The search for dark matter addresses one of the fundamental questions in particle astrophysics. Current models predict that our galaxy is encased in a halo of dark matter. As the Sun orbits around the galaxy and the Earth around the Sun, we expect there to be an annual modulation in the flux of dark matter that passes through the Earth. If the modulation observed by the DAMA experiment in Italy is due to dark matter, an experiment in the Southern Hemisphere with the same target material would expect to observe modulations with the same phase and amplitude. This would be unambiguous evidence for the observation of dark matter. If the modulation is due to an environmental background related to the seasons, it will be opposite in the two hemispheres.

This award will fund an integrated research and education program focused on the development of sodium iodide-(NaI)-based detectors for dark matter physics. The research program consists of three main activities: analysis of data from a 17 kilogram NaI detector currently operating 2500 meters below the surface in the South Pole ice, a systematic study of the characteristics and pulse shape discrimination techniques of NaI detectors, and the simulations and sensitivity studies for a proposed 250 kilogram NaI detector to be mounted in the Southern Hemisphere.

Broader impacts: This award will also fund a series of educational and outreach activities designed to recruit and retain physics majors and physicists in STEM fields by showcasing the wide range of careers available to physicists. A special focus will be given to recruit and retain women, persons with disabilities, and underrepresented minorities in physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Astrophysical observations and cosmological data have led to the conclusion that nearly a quarter of the Universe consists of dark matter. This non-luminous dark matter manifests itself through gravity and has so far eluded direct detection and we do not yet know what it is. Weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs) are a theoretically favored candidate for dark matter.

An expected, observable signature of dark matter is the annual modulation in the rate of WIMP-nucleon interactions taking place in an Earth-bound experiment. Currently, the only claim for a direct detection of dark matter comes from the observation of an annual modulation signal by the DAMA experiment, first reported in 1997. By now the modulation exceeds a significance of > 9-sigma but the interpretation of the annual modulation signal as a sign of dark matter has met much skepticism. No known backgrounds or unaccounted systematic effects can demonstratively explain their observation. On the other hand there has not been an independent experimental confirmation of this extraordinary claim.

With this award, the NSF supported work the PI and her group members to lay the groundwork for testing DAMA collaboration’s claim. The PI led an international collaboration that built the DM-Ice17 Experiment as an extension to the IceCube Neutrino Observatory. The detectors are still running at the South Pole. DM-Ice17 consists of 17 kg of thallium-doped sodium iodide detectors housed in two stainless steel pressure vessels. The detectors are buried just below IceCube, at 2,500 m deep in the Antarctic glacial ice near the South Pole. The group analyzed 3.6 years of data from DM-Ice17 and determined that the Antarctic ice, even after IceCube’s ice drilling process, is sufficiently clean to carry out  a dark matter experiment. With this, we established the South Pole as a viable location to carry out direct detection dark matter experiments. 

We also carried out extensive R&D in creating sodium-iodide detectors that meet the background criteria for testing DAMA. In collaboration with a commercial vendor, Alpha Spectra Inc. of Grand Junction, CO, we have achieved a background rate of 2 counts/keV/kg/day in the region of interest of 2 – 10 keV. This is a factor of twenty lower than what is typically available commercially. The improvement in the purity of the crystals also improves their light yield. Sodium iodide crystals are used in a wide range of applications including medical imaging and oil well characterization. A high light yield results in improved energy resolution - a desired characteristic for all applications. 

With these crystals, DM-Ice17 and KIMS collaborations joined to form a new experiment named COSINE-100. The experiment consists of 106 kg of sodium iodide detectors, is located at the Yanyang Underground Laboratory in South Korea, and has the sensitivity to definitively test DAMA in 5 years. The award supported the personnel from the Yale group to participate in the construction, commissioning, and operation of COSINE-100. We began taking data in September 2016 and have already begun to rule out several dark matter models as the origin of DAMA’s signal. COSINE-100 will continue to run for several more years to carry out a definitive and model independent test.

The PI has mentored six PhD students under this award; four has obtained their degrees thus far. Two have gone onto do postdoc positions in physics, one is a lecturer at a four-year college, and one has gone into the financial industry. She has also mentored four postdoctoral researchers under this project, all of whom are employed either at academic institutions or other STEM fields. The PI has successfully graduated and mentored undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs who are underrepresented minorities. Her group consistently has 50% women and several URM students and postdocs.
